title: Write design-philosophy.md
description:
Write complete docs/concepts/design-philosophy.md explaining JIT's design principles.

## Current State

File exists at docs/concepts/design-philosophy.md (29 lines) with section headings only:
- Domain Agnostic
- Agent-First Design
- Functional Programming Principles
- CLI as Primary Interface
- Dogfooding

## Content Needed

### 1. Domain Agnostic (~80-100 lines)
- Why JIT avoids software-specific terminology
- Issue/Gate/Dependency work across domains
- Configurable workflows for different contexts
- **Examples:**
  - Software: Issue=Feature/Bug, Gate=CI check
  - Research: Issue=Experiment, Gate=Peer review
  - Knowledge work: Issue=Document, Gate=Approval
- Domain mapping table

### 2. Agent-First Design (~80-100 lines)
- Built for programmatic agents, humans benefit too
- Why this design choice matters
- **Key principles:**
  - JSON-first output (--json flag everywhere)
  - Atomic file operations (no race conditions)
  - Clear exit codes for scripting
  - MCP protocol integration
  - Structured errors
- **Examples:** Multi-agent claiming, coordination patterns

### 3. Functional Programming Principles (~80-100 lines)
- Immutability where practical
- Pure functions over stateful objects
- Iterator combinators over explicit loops
- Expression-oriented code
- **Why it matters:**
  - Easier to reason about
  - Better testability
  - Fewer bugs
  - Composability
- **Examples from codebase:**
  - Query functions using .filter().map()
  - Result/Option for error handling

### 4. CLI as Primary Interface (~80-100 lines)
- Why CLI over web-first?
- **Benefits:**
  - Scriptability and automation
  - Agent-friendly by default
  - UNIX philosophy (do one thing well)
  - Composable with other tools
- MCP and web UI built on CLI foundation
- Human ergonomics (short hashes, --quiet mode)

### 5. Dogfooding (~80-100 lines)
- We use JIT to track JIT development
- Real-world validation of design decisions
- Continuous feedback loop
- **Specific examples:**
  - This very repository uses JIT
  - Gate system tested on our own workflow
  - Documentation tracked as issues
  - Multi-agent coordination proven in practice
- **Benefits:**
  - Catches usability issues early
  - Validates agent orchestration claims
  - Ensures production readiness

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All 5 sections complete (400-500 lines total)
- [ ] Each section explains *why* not just *what*
- [ ] Real examples from JIT codebase/usage
- [ ] Cross-references to other docs (concepts, how-tos)
- [ ] Maintains neutral, educational tone
- [ ] Domain-agnostic language (per strategy)
